p: In parallel, we tested the same brains to detect SORL1-fl transcripts. In line with previous reports that showed robust SORLA expression in AD cerebellum [ 5, 30], we did also not see any difference for SORL1-fl levels between AD and non-demented controls (Fig. 4c). Quantification of the hybridization signal for the E38E39 probe showed that the majority of PCs (67.3%) expresses high levels of SORL1-fl transcript (group III), and that none of the four groups were affected by AD (group 0, p = 0.4197; group I, p = 0.4674; group II, p = 0.8955; group III, p = 0.5474) (Fig. 4c). Similarly, we did not observe any decrease in the signal for SORL1-fl in the GCL (Fig. 4d). These findings confirmed SORL1-fl is abundantly and robustly expressed in the human cerebellum, and its expression is not affected by AD in this brain region.
